title: TomPegden published Unite union leadership hopefuls bring their battle to Leicestersh...
text:
Speaking after the nomination meeting, Mr Coyne said: "Across the country, Unite members are saying it's time for a change. 
"They want the union to start putting members' interests first again. 
"As general secretary, my focus will be solely on protecting our members' jobs, wages and conditions. 
"With Britain leaving the European Union and taking back control of our borders, we will have to improve skills and training throughout our economy to remain competitive. 
"I will make skills the top priority of Unite, so we can secure more good, high-wage jobs for our members." 
Mr McCluskey, who is seeking reelection, visited the Caterpillar plant in Desford telling members the East Midlands would be a test of the Government's industrial strategy. 
He said he wanted Westminster to "get serious" about flagship Midlands companies such as Caterpillar and Derbyshire's Bombardier, whose fortunes have fluctuated over the years. 
He said: "With Theresa May now pursuing a hard Brexit, which threatens to deprive our manufacturers of access to tariff-free access to the European single market, the Prime Minister must work with trade unions in achieving an industrial strategy that provides new money, real investment and guarantees that contracts remain in Britain, and in the East Midlands. 
"I'll bang on the door of number 10 until she does because, while the majority of people in the East Midlands voted to be out of Europe, they didn't vote to be out of work. 
"Brexit presents the varied industries and diverse communities of this region with profound challenges. 
"About 200,000 jobs in this region are dependent on EU exports, which are worth around Â£8.9 million. 
"Continued tariff-free access to the EU single market is necessary for the East Midlands to sustain its status generating world-leading jobs, skills and revenue for the UK." 
Ian Allinson is campaigning on a ticket of being the "grassroots socialist candidate".
